Sorry...hit the wrong key!!!  Let me resend this...

G'day Rich - 

My opin=
ions are based largely on "gut feeling" when seeing the guard since, on pho=
tographs at least, these groups do resemble each other. Having the tsuba in=
-hand would of course make for a stronger argument for (or against) the gro=
ups mentioned, I would think. 

Maybe I shouldn't had called the edge treat=
ment "bones" but it would be the lines visiable from the three-fold constru=
ction of Akasaka. Last year I purchased a wonderful "willow tree" iron suka=
shi tsuba, mumei--one of my "dream" tsuba ever since Sasano illustrated thi=
s motif in his sukashi tsuba book. I felt it was Akasaka and it did have th=
ese linear lines (bones?) in its edge. Jim Gilbert and Henrik Eschbaum...

=
(Was checking a spelling and accidently "sent" this...hope I got the right =
name here!)

Anyway, they did agree to Akasaka and pointed out this layerin=
g which was quite evident on this tsuba. Of course, I was thrilled. In this=
 case the guard could had been Kyo-sukashi or even Higo. It brought some ni=
ce discussion.

As for Tosa Myochin, I have not had a lot of experience wit=
h their work but do think the plate might not be a "good" compared to Akasa=
ka. They also often used the "mustache" type chiseling around the nakago-an=
a. Your tsuba does not show this (nor does one I have that is signed Tosa M=
yochin). When I see the surface decoration as is in your tsuba, I must admi=
t it shoots me to Nishigaki group. Interesting to compare this treatment of=
 the various Higo groups illustrated in Sasano's books. 

Exciting tsuba, a=
ll!!  Again, sorry for the incomplete earlier email. 

Ron
STL
